title: N. V. Krishnaiah
text:
N. V. Krishnaiah (also known as NVK) was a <a href="communism">communist</a> politician from <a href="Andhra%20Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. He was a municipal councillor in <a href="Nellore">Nellore</a>, member of the Andhra Pradesh legislature, president of the <a href="Indian%20Federation%20of%20Trade%20Unions">Indian Federation of Trade Unions</a> and a central leader in the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20%28Kanu%20Sanyal%29">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist)</a>.
NVK was born in 1930 in Yataluru village, <a href="Venkatagiri">Venkatagiri</a> mandal, <a href="Nellore%20district">Nellore district</a>. He completed high school in Venkatagiri and then moved to Nellore to join <a href="V.R.%20College">V.R. College</a>. At V.R. College he joined the students movement and later became a member of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India">Communist Party</a> in 1952.
He then returned to Venkatagiri and began to work in the <a href="All%20India%20Kisan%20Sabha">peasant front</a> of the party. In 1957 he shifted his activities to Nellore and became a <a href="trade%20union">trade union</a> organizer amongst motor workers. In both cases he led militant campaigns and came into conflicts with landlords and private bus company owners.
When the <a href="1964%20split%20in%20the%20Communist%20Party%20of%20India">Communist Party of India was divided</a>, NVK sided with the leftist tendency. He became the secretary of the Nellore town committee and a member of the Nellore district committee of the new party, the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist%29">Communist Party of India (Marxist)</a>. In 1964 he was elected to the Municipal Corporation of Nellore.
NVK contested the 1967 <a href="Andhra%20Pradesh">Andhra Pradesh</a> <a href="Vidhan%20Sabha">Legislative Assembly</a> election as a CPI(M) candidate in the Nellore constituency. He came second with 11951 votes (25.89%). He was defeated by the <a href="Bharatiya%20Jan%20Sangh">Jan Sangh</a> candidate <a href="M.%20R.%20Annadata">M. R. Annadata</a>.
At the same time, the CPI(M) in Andhra Pradesh faced another split. Large sections of the regional party cadres began to condemn the CPI(M) leadership as 'neo-revisionist'. Led by <a href="T.N.%20Reddy">T.N. Reddy</a>, the radical elements rallied around the <a href="Andhra%20Pradesh%20Coordination%20Committee%20of%20Communist%20Revolutionaries">Andhra Pradesh Coordination Committee of Communist Revolutionaries</a>. NVK joined the APCCCR, and as a consequence he later resigned from his position as a municipal councillor.
NVK was one of the accused in the Hyderabad Conspiracy Case. During the period of 1968-1978, he was frequently jailed, and spent over five years in imprisonment. When the APCCCR was divided in 1971, NVK sided with the <a href="Chandra%20Pulla%20Reddy">Chandra Pulla Reddy</a>-led faction. This grouping merged into the <a href="PCC%2C%20CPI%28ML%29">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist)</a>
After being released from jail in 1978, he became involved in trade union activities. He became the president of the <a href="Indian%20Federation%20of%20Trade%20Unions">Indian Federation of Trade Unions</a>. In 1980 he sided with C.P. Reddy, who broke away and formed <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20%28Chandra%20Pulla%20Reddy%29">his own CPI(ML)</a>.
In the 1989 Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly election, NVK contested the <a href="Sircilla">Sircilla</a> seat as an <a href="Independent%20%28politician%29">independent</a>. He won with 26430 votes (29.84%). During his legislative tenure, he raised over 2500 questions in the assembly. One of the issues he highlighted was the need for irrigation in the <a href="Karimnagar">Karimnagar</a> area.
Following the 1994 Legislative Assembly election, CPI(ML) Janashakti was divided. NVK became the leader of a break-away group, the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20Janashakti%20COC">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Janashakti COC</a>. Later, CPI(ML) Janashakti COC would merge with the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20New%20Initiative">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) New Initiative</a> of Arvind Sinha and form the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20Unity%20Initiative">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Unity Initiative</a>. CPI(ML) Unity Initiative then merged with the <a href="Communist%20Organisation%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29">Communist Organisation of India (Marxist-Leninist)</a> of <a href="Kanu%20Sanyal">Kanu Sanyal</a> to form the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20%28Kanu%20Sanyal%29">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist)</a>. In January 2005, the <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20India%20%28Marxist-Leninist%29%20Red%20Flag">Communist Party of India (Marxist-Leninist) Red Flag</a> merged into the CPI(ML) led by Sanyal, at a conference in <a href="Vijayawada">Vijayawada</a>. NVK became a <a href="Central%20Committee">Central Committee</a> member of the unified CPI(ML).
NVK died on 13 September 2006.
